Multiway graphs and tables

Richard Layton

2021-06-26

Source: vignettes/art-01-multiway.Rmd
art-01-multiway.Rmd

Introduction

We take some time in this early tutorial to create some graphs because, as Wickham and Grolemund state [1],

Visualization is a great place to start with R programming, because the payoff is so clear; you get to make elegant and informative plots that help you understand the data.

In particular, we introduce graphs of multiway data in which there is is one quantitative variable and two categorical variables. As explained by Cleveland [2],

… the quantitative variable is a response, and the goal is to study how it depends on the categorical variables, which are factors. What distinguishes multiway data is the cross-classification of the categorical variables; there is a value of the response for each combination of levels of the two categorical variables.

The structure of multiway data is specific: a categorical variable with \(m\) levels; an independent categorical variable with \(n\) levels; and a single quantitative value associated with every combinations of levels of the two categories. Multiway data are typically organized as three columns with \(m \times n\) rows.

Note that “multiway” in our context refers to the data structure and graph design defined by Cleveland, not to the methods of analysis described by Kroonenberg [3].

Outline

  • Start with the case study stickiness results (study_stickiness)
  • Practice conditioning multiway data for display
  • Practice creating multiway graphs and their duals
  • Practice tabulating multiway data

This vignette uses

midfieldr functions

  • condition_multiway()

packages

# packages used
library("midfieldr")
library("data.table")
library("ggplot2")

We can control how a data.table is printed to the screen with the following options.

# optional code to control data.table printing
options(
  datatable.print.nrows = 10,
  datatable.print.topn = 5,
  datatable.print.class = TRUE
)

Prepare data

Longitudinal “stickiness” is the ratio of the number of students graduating in a program to the number of students ever enrolled in that program [4]. The stickiness metric is developed in a separate vignette—here we focus on graphing a result.

We computed stickiness for a case study in Civil, Electrical, Industrial, and Mechanical Engineering and saved the results as the data set, study_stickiness. You may view its help page by running

? study_stickiness

The data is loaded with midfieldr (we don’t have to use data() to access it.)

# examine the built-in data
study_stickiness
#>                    program             race_sex stick
#>                     <char>               <char> <num>
#>  1:      Civil Engineering         Asian Female  70.6
#>  2:      Civil Engineering         Black Female  51.9
#>  3:      Civil Engineering         White Female  70.5
#>  4:      Civil Engineering           Asian Male  64.9
#>  5:      Civil Engineering           Black Male  43.9
#> ---                                                  
#> 27: Mechanical Engineering           Asian Male  63.1
#> 28: Mechanical Engineering           Black Male  46.7
#> 29: Mechanical Engineering Hispanic/Latinx Male  61.8
#> 30: Mechanical Engineering Native American Male  57.1
#> 31: Mechanical Engineering           White Male  65.2

Categorical variables are often provided as character variables. Without ordering the levels, the rows and panels of the multiway graph are ordered alphabetically—not the best design for gaining insights from the graph.

To condition the categorical variables, we use condition_multiway() to convert them to factors with levels ordered by the median response values. To see its help page, run

? condition_multiway()
# create a new memory location
DT <- copy(study_stickiness)

The quantitative variable is stick (stickiness); the first categorical variable is program; the second categorical variable is race/ethnicity/sex. Before conditioning, the categorical variables are characters,

# first category is a character
class(DT$program)
#> [1] "character"

# second category is a character
class(DT$race_sex)
#> [1] "character"

We process the data frame

# condition as multiway data
DT <- condition_multiway(DT)

No change to the row and column structure, but as you can see, the previous character variables have been converted to factors,

DT
#>                    program             race_sex stick
#>                     <fctr>               <fctr> <num>
#>  1:      Civil Engineering         Asian Female  70.6
#>  2:      Civil Engineering         Black Female  51.9
#>  3:      Civil Engineering         White Female  70.5
#>  4:      Civil Engineering           Asian Male  64.9
#>  5:      Civil Engineering           Black Male  43.9
#> ---                                                  
#> 27: Mechanical Engineering           Asian Male  63.1
#> 28: Mechanical Engineering           Black Male  46.7
#> 29: Mechanical Engineering Hispanic/Latinx Male  61.8
#> 30: Mechanical Engineering Native American Male  57.1
#> 31: Mechanical Engineering           White Male  65.2

The levels of the factors are ordered non-alphabetically. program is now a factor with 4 levels; race_sex is a factor with 9 levels.

# first category is now a factor
levels(DT$program)
#> [1] "Industrial Engineering" "Mechanical Engineering" "Electrical Engineering"
#> [4] "Civil Engineering"

# second category is now a factor
levels(DT$race_sex)
#> [1] "Black Male"             "Black Female"           "Native American Male"  
#> [4] "Hispanic/Latinx Male"   "Asian Male"             "White Female"          
#> [7] "White Male"             "Asian Female"           "Hispanic/Latinx Female"

We would expect 4 \(\times\) 9 = 36 observations. However, some rows are omitted to preserve confidentiality, leaving us with 31 observations.

The median values that determine the order of the levels can be obtained by using the details argument.

# return median stickiness by category
DT_med <- condition_multiway(DT, details = TRUE)

By ordering the data by program, you can see that a given program has a single value of med_program copied as many times as needed.

# optional code to control data.table printing
options(datatable.print.topn = 10)

# programs have a median stickiness across race-sex groups
DT_med[order(program)]
#>                    program               race_sex med_program med_race_sex
#>                     <fctr>                 <fctr>       <num>        <num>
#>  1: Industrial Engineering           Asian Female       60.70        70.85
#>  2: Industrial Engineering           Black Female       60.70        56.95
#>  3: Industrial Engineering           White Female       60.70        65.10
#>  4: Industrial Engineering             Asian Male       60.70        63.90
#>  5: Industrial Engineering             Black Male       60.70        45.90
#>  6: Industrial Engineering   Hispanic/Latinx Male       60.70        60.35
#>  7: Industrial Engineering             White Male       60.70        65.10
#>  8: Mechanical Engineering           Asian Female       63.10        70.85
#>  9: Mechanical Engineering           Black Female       63.10        56.95
#> 10: Mechanical Engineering Hispanic/Latinx Female       63.10        72.05
#> ---                                                                       
#> 22: Electrical Engineering             Black Male       63.45        45.90
#> 23: Electrical Engineering   Hispanic/Latinx Male       63.45        60.35
#> 24: Electrical Engineering             White Male       63.45        65.10
#> 25:      Civil Engineering           Asian Female       64.90        70.85
#> 26:      Civil Engineering           Black Female       64.90        56.95
#> 27:      Civil Engineering           White Female       64.90        65.10
#> 28:      Civil Engineering             Asian Male       64.90        63.90
#> 29:      Civil Engineering             Black Male       64.90        45.90
#> 30:      Civil Engineering   Hispanic/Latinx Male       64.90        60.35
#> 31:      Civil Engineering             White Male       64.90        65.10
#>     stick
#>     <num>
#>  1:  50.0
#>  2:  58.5
#>  3:  60.7
#>  4:  63.3
#>  5:  53.8
#>  6:  88.0
#>  7:  65.0
#>  8:  82.6
#>  9:  55.4
#> 10:  72.7
#> ---      
#> 22:  45.1
#> 23:  55.2
#> 24:  63.7
#> 25:  70.6
#> 26:  51.9
#> 27:  70.5
#> 28:  64.9
#> 29:  43.9
#> 30:  58.9
#> 31:  68.3

Similarly, by ordering the data by race_sex, you can see that a given demographic group has a single value of med_race_sex copied as many times as needed.

# race_sex groupings have a median stickiness across programs
DT_med[order(race_sex)]
#>                    program               race_sex med_program med_race_sex
#>                     <fctr>                 <fctr>       <num>        <num>
#>  1:      Civil Engineering             Black Male       64.90        45.90
#>  2: Electrical Engineering             Black Male       63.45        45.90
#>  3: Industrial Engineering             Black Male       60.70        45.90
#>  4: Mechanical Engineering             Black Male       63.10        45.90
#>  5:      Civil Engineering           Black Female       64.90        56.95
#>  6: Electrical Engineering           Black Female       63.45        56.95
#>  7: Industrial Engineering           Black Female       60.70        56.95
#>  8: Mechanical Engineering           Black Female       63.10        56.95
#>  9: Mechanical Engineering   Native American Male       63.10        57.10
#> 10:      Civil Engineering   Hispanic/Latinx Male       64.90        60.35
#> ---                                                                       
#> 22:      Civil Engineering             White Male       64.90        65.10
#> 23: Electrical Engineering             White Male       63.45        65.10
#> 24: Industrial Engineering             White Male       60.70        65.10
#> 25: Mechanical Engineering             White Male       63.10        65.10
#> 26:      Civil Engineering           Asian Female       64.90        70.85
#> 27: Electrical Engineering           Asian Female       63.45        70.85
#> 28: Industrial Engineering           Asian Female       60.70        70.85
#> 29: Mechanical Engineering           Asian Female       63.10        70.85
#> 30: Electrical Engineering Hispanic/Latinx Female       63.45        72.05
#> 31: Mechanical Engineering Hispanic/Latinx Female       63.10        72.05

#> 10:  58.9

Exercises

  1. Determine the class of the categorical variables in the built-in data set study_grad_rate.
  2. Apply condition_multiway(). Confirm that the categorical variables are factors.
  3. Determine the order of the factor levels.

Create a multiway graph

We use conventional ggplot2 functions to create the multiway graphs.

By previously ordering the levels of the factors, we have structured the data so that the rows and panels of the multiway graph are ordered by the appropriate medians. The panel medians are drawn as vertical dashed lines.

Reminder: These are practice data, not suitable for drawing inferences about student performance, i.e., not for research.

# create one multiway graph
ggplot(data = DT_med, aes(x = stick, y = race_sex)) +
  facet_wrap(vars(program), ncol = 1, as.table = FALSE) +
  geom_vline(aes(xintercept = med_program),
    linetype = 2,
    color = "gray70"
  ) +
  geom_point(na.rm = TRUE) +
  labs(
    x = "Stickiness",
    y = "",
    title = "Practice data (not for research)",
    caption = "Source: midfielddata"
  )


This graph permits a direct visual comparison of how stickiness varies by race and sex within a particular major.

Reading a multiway graph

  • We can more effectively compare values within a panel than between panels.
  • Because rows are ordered, one expects a generally increasing trend within a panel. A response greater or smaller than expected creates a visual asymmetry. The interesting stories are often in these visual anomalies.
  • To explore the comparison between panels, we swap the row and panel categories, creating the dual multiway.

Exercise

  1. Create a multiway graph using the conditioned study_grad_rate data

Create the dual multiway graph

The previous graph does not facilitate visual comparisons of members of the same race-sex group. As Cleveland says,

Because of this asymmetry, it is often important to explore multiway data by as many multiway dot plots as there are categorical variables, with each variable assigned once to the levels.

To create the dual multiway graph, we swap the roles of the rows and panels.

  • y = race_sex becomes y = program
  • facet_wrap(vars(program) ... becomes facet_wrap(vars(race_sex) ... 
# create the dual multiway graph
ggplot(data = DT_med, aes(x = stick, y = program)) +
  facet_wrap(vars(race_sex), ncol = 1, as.table = FALSE) +
  geom_vline(aes(xintercept = med_race_sex),
    linetype = 2,
    color = "gray70"
  ) +
  geom_point(na.rm = TRUE) +
  labs(
    x = "Stickiness",
    y = "",
    title = "Practice data (not for research)",
    caption = "Source: midfielddata"
  )


This graph permits a direct visual comparison of how stickiness varies by major for one group of students.

Both multiways should be created for discussion. Usually one or the other will convey a more compelling visual story that gets included in the published findings.

Exercise

  1. Create the dual multiway graph using the conditioned study_grad_rate data

Tabulate multiway data

Data tables are useful in discussions with one’s research team and are often included in publications for readers who want to see the values underlying the data graphics.

Our example data are currently laid out in “block record” form [5], where the race_sex key and the program key are both in columns and the response, stickiness, is in the last column. This layout is also called “tidy data” [1].

The graphing package we use, ggplot2, is designed to work most effectively with block-record data, thus the block-record (“long”) form is the default layout in midfieldr.

Table 1: Stickiness (block records)
program race_sex stick med_program med_race_sex
Civil Engineering Asian Female 70.6 64.90 70.85
Civil Engineering Black Female 51.9 64.90 56.95
Civil Engineering White Female 70.5 64.90 65.10
Civil Engineering Asian Male 64.9 64.90 63.90
Civil Engineering Black Male 43.9 64.90 45.90
Civil Engineering Hispanic/Latinx Male 58.9 64.90 60.35
Civil Engineering White Male 68.3 64.90 65.10
Electrical Engineering Asian Female 71.1 63.45 70.85
Electrical Engineering Black Female 61.7 63.45 56.95
Electrical Engineering Hispanic/Latinx Female 71.4 63.45 72.05
Electrical Engineering White Female 63.2 63.45 65.10
Electrical Engineering Asian Male 64.5 63.45 63.90
Electrical Engineering Black Male 45.1 63.45 45.90
Electrical Engineering Hispanic/Latinx Male 55.2 63.45 60.35
Electrical Engineering White Male 63.7 63.45 65.10
Industrial Engineering Asian Female 50.0 60.70 70.85
Industrial Engineering Black Female 58.5 60.70 56.95
Industrial Engineering White Female 60.7 60.70 65.10
Industrial Engineering Asian Male 63.3 60.70 63.90
Industrial Engineering Black Male 53.8 60.70 45.90
Industrial Engineering Hispanic/Latinx Male 88.0 60.70 60.35
Industrial Engineering White Male 65.0 60.70 65.10
Mechanical Engineering Asian Female 82.6 63.10 70.85
Mechanical Engineering Black Female 55.4 63.10 56.95
Mechanical Engineering Hispanic/Latinx Female 72.7 63.10 72.05
Mechanical Engineering White Female 67.0 63.10 65.10
Mechanical Engineering Asian Male 63.1 63.10 63.90
Mechanical Engineering Black Male 46.7 63.10 45.90
Mechanical Engineering Hispanic/Latinx Male 61.8 63.10 60.35
Mechanical Engineering Native American Male 57.1 63.10 57.10
Mechanical Engineering White Male 65.2 63.10 65.10


However, the visual convention preferred by publishers and readers is a row-record (“wide”) form, as illustrated by Table 2. The race_sex key is in the left column and the program key is in the column names. The stickiness findings lie at the row-column intersections. Note that in this form, the four NA observations we mentioned earlier are explicitly shown.

Table 2: Stickiness (row records)
Race/ethnicity/sex Civil Electrical Industrial Mechanical
Asian Female 70.6 71.1 50.0 82.6
Asian Male 64.9 64.5 63.3 63.1
Black Female 51.9 61.7 58.5 55.4
Black Male 43.9 45.1 53.8 46.7
Hispanic/Latinx Female NA 71.4 NA 72.7
Hispanic/Latinx Male 58.9 55.2 88.0 61.8
Native American Male NA NA NA 57.1
White Female 70.5 63.2 60.7 67.0
White Male 68.3 63.7 65.0 65.2

Depending on your software background, you may have encountered a block-record/row-record transformation using any of these function pairs—a list adapted from [5].

  • pivot / anti-pivot or crosstab / shred (databases)
  • pivot_to_rowrecs / unpivot_to_blocks (cdata)
  • reshape “wide” / reshape “long” (R)
  • pivot_wider / pivot_longer (tidyr)
  • pivot / unpivot (Microsoft Excel)
  • dcast / melt (data.table)
  • cast / melt (reshape2)

In our example, we use dcast() from the data.table package to reshape the data for publication. We start by limiting the significant figures of floating-point numbers.

# create a new memory location
block_form <- copy(DT)

# limit significant digits
block_form[, stick := round(stick, 2)]

If in the final result we want rows and columns ordered alphabetically, we convert factors to characters.

# create a new memory location
row_form <- copy(block_form)

# convert factors to characters
row_form[, race_sex := as.character(race_sex)]
row_form[, program := as.character(program)]

dcast() is used to reshape the data frame from block-record form to row-record form.

# reshape
row_form <- dcast(row_form, race_sex ~ program, value.var = "stick")

# examine the result
row_form
#>                  race_sex Civil Engineering Electrical Engineering
#>                    <char>             <num>                  <num>
#> 1:           Asian Female              70.6                   71.1
#> 2:             Asian Male              64.9                   64.5
#> 3:           Black Female              51.9                   61.7
#> 4:             Black Male              43.9                   45.1
#> 5: Hispanic/Latinx Female                NA                   71.4
#> 6:   Hispanic/Latinx Male              58.9                   55.2
#> 7:   Native American Male                NA                     NA
#> 8:           White Female              70.5                   63.2
#> 9:             White Male              68.3                   63.7
#>    Industrial Engineering Mechanical Engineering
#>                     <num>                  <num>
#> 1:                   50.0                   82.6
#> 2:                   63.3                   63.1
#> 3:                   58.5                   55.4
#> 4:                   53.8                   46.7
#> 5:                     NA                   72.7
#> 6:                   88.0                   61.8
#> 7:                     NA                   57.1
#> 8:                   60.7                   67.0
#> 9:                   65.0                   65.2

For publication, we edit the new column names.

# edit column names
setnames(row_form,
  old = c(
    "race_sex",
    "Civil Engineering",
    "Electrical Engineering",
    "Industrial Engineering",
    "Mechanical Engineering"
  ),
  new = c(
    "Race/ethnicity/sex",
    "Civil",
    "Electrical",
    "Industrial",
    "Mechanical"
  )
)

# examine the result
row_form
#>        Race/ethnicity/sex Civil Electrical Industrial Mechanical
#>                    <char> <num>      <num>      <num>      <num>
#> 1:           Asian Female  70.6       71.1       50.0       82.6
#> 2:             Asian Male  64.9       64.5       63.3       63.1
#> 3:           Black Female  51.9       61.7       58.5       55.4
#> 4:             Black Male  43.9       45.1       53.8       46.7
#> 5: Hispanic/Latinx Female    NA       71.4         NA       72.7
#> 6:   Hispanic/Latinx Male  58.9       55.2       88.0       61.8
#> 7:   Native American Male    NA         NA         NA       57.1
#> 8:           White Female  70.5       63.2       60.7       67.0
#> 9:             White Male  68.3       63.7       65.0       65.2

This result is the source for Table 2, repeated below.

Table 2: Stickiness (row records)
Race/ethnicity/sex Civil Electrical Industrial Mechanical
Asian Female 70.6 71.1 50.0 82.6
Asian Male 64.9 64.5 63.3 63.1
Black Female 51.9 61.7 58.5 55.4
Black Male 43.9 45.1 53.8 46.7
Hispanic/Latinx Female NA 71.4 NA 72.7
Hispanic/Latinx Male 58.9 55.2 88.0 61.8
Native American Male NA NA NA 57.1
White Female 70.5 63.2 60.7 67.0
White Male 68.3 63.7 65.0 65.2

Other good tools for reshaping are provided in packages such as reshape() in base R, cdata [6], and tidyr [7].

Exercise

  1. Create a table of study_grad_rate data similar to the table above.

ᐸ Getting started     Program codes ᐳ


Appendix

Complete script

The vignette code chunks are collected below in a single, condensed script.

# packages used
library("midfieldr")
library("data.table")
library("ggplot2")

# optional code to control data.table printing
options(
  datatable.print.nrows = 10,
  datatable.print.topn = 5,
  datatable.print.class = TRUE
)

# data preparation
DT <- copy(study_stickiness)
class(DT$program)
class(DT$race_sex)
DT <- condition_multiway(DT)
levels(DT$program)
levels(DT$race_sex)
DT_med <- condition_multiway(DT, details = TRUE)
DT_med[order(program)]
DT_med[order(race_sex)]

# creating a multiway graph
ggplot(data = DT_med, aes(x = stick, y = race_sex)) +
  facet_wrap(vars(program), ncol = 1, as.table = FALSE) +
  geom_vline(aes(xintercept = med_program),
    linetype = 2
  ) +
  geom_point(na.rm = TRUE) +
  labs(
    x = "Stickiness",
    y = "",
    title = "Practice data (not for research)",
    caption = "Source: midfielddata"
  )

# creating the dual multiway graph
ggplot(data = DT_med, aes(x = stick, y = program)) +
  facet_wrap(vars(race_sex), ncol = 1, as.table = FALSE) +
  geom_vline(aes(xintercept = med_race_sex),
    linetype = 2
  ) +
  geom_point(na.rm = TRUE) +
  labs(
    x = "Stickiness",
    y = "",
    title = "Practice data (not for research)",
    caption = "Source: midfielddata"
  )

# creating a table for publication
block_form <- copy(DT)
block_form[, stick := round(stick, 2)]
row_form <- copy(block_form)
row_form[, race_sex := as.character(race_sex)]
row_form[, program := as.character(program)]
row_form <- dcast(row_form, race_sex ~ program, value.var = "stick")
setnames(row_form,
  old = c(
    "race_sex",
    "Civil Engineering",
    "Electrical Engineering",
    "Industrial Engineering",
    "Mechanical Engineering"
  ),
  new = c(
    "Race/ethnicity/sex",
    "Civil",
    "Electrical",
    "Industrial",
    "Mechanical"
  )
)
